## com_vmware_vcenter_lcm_reports

**Description:** The Report service provides an operation to download the report generated by the interop and precheck operations. To download a report, you must use the Reports.get operation. A Report.Location structure represents the location of the file which has Report.Token structure which represents the token ID (@name String) and the expiration time of the token Report.Token.expiry DateTime. Report.Location structure also has the URI for the file which needs to be downloaded.

### Methods

#### `com_vmware_vcenter_lcm_reports`
Auto-generated constructor

**Parameters:**
| Name | Type | Description |
| :--- | :--- | :--- |
| `client` | `VAPIClient` | vAPI client |

**Returns:** `void`

---

#### `get`
Returns the location Reports.Location information for downloading the report for the specified file name. Retrieving a report involves two steps: - Step 1: Invoke the Reports.get operation to provision a token and a URI. - Step 2: Make an HTTP GET request by using the URI and the token returned in step 1 to retrieve the report. The HTTP GET request will: - Return 401 (Not Authorized) if the download URI is recognized, but the token is invalid, 404 if the URL is not recognized otherwise return 200 (OK) - Provide the CSV contents as the output of the request. The API accepts the file name as input, reads the contents of that CSV file, and returns this text as the result of the API. if you do not have all of the privileges described as follows: - Operation execution requires VcLifecycle.View.

**Parameters:**
| Name | Type | Description |
| :--- | :--- | :--- |
| `report` | `string` | The parameter must be an identifier for the resource type: com.vmware.vcenter.lcm.report. |

**Returns:** `com_vmware_vcenter_lcm_reports_location`

---

### Attributes

## com_vmware_vcenter_namespace__management_software_clusters

**Description:** The Clusters service provides operations to upgrade the vSphere clusters.

### Methods

#### `com_vmware_vcenter_namespace__management_software_clusters`
Auto-generated constructor

**Parameters:**
| Name | Type | Description |
| :--- | :--- | :--- |
| `client` | `VAPIClient` | vAPI client |

**Returns:** `void`

---

#### `upgrade`
Upgrade the cluster to a specific version. This operation upgrades the components on control plane VMs and worker plane hosts based on the selected version. Before upgrading, this operation performs pre-checks and sets the evaluation response in Info.UpgradeStatus.messages with various Message.Severity levels. Depending on the severity, the upgrade may or may not proceed beyond prechecks. Here is a list of severities and corresponding behavior: - ERROR: Upgrade does not proceed beyond precheck operation - WARNING: Upgrade proceeds beyond precheck operation only if UpgradeSpec.ignorePrecheckWarnings is set to true - INFO: Upgrade proceeds beyond precheck operation uninterrupted if you do not have all of the privileges described as follows: - The resource ClusterComputeResource referenced by the parameter cluster requires Namespaces.Upgrade.

**Parameters:**
| Name | Type | Description |
| :--- | :--- | :--- |
| `cluster` | `string` | Identifier for the cluster which will be upgraded. The parameter must be an identifier for the resource type: ClusterComputeResource. |
| `spec` | `com_vmware_vcenter_namespace__management_software_clusters_upgrade__spec` | Specification for upgrading the cluster. |

**Returns:** `void`

---

#### `get`
Returns upgrade related information of a specific cluster. if you do not have all of the privileges described as follows: - The resource ClusterComputeResource referenced by the parameter cluster requires System.Read.

**Parameters:**
| Name | Type | Description |
| :--- | :--- | :--- |
| `cluster` | `string` | Identifier for the cluster which will be upgraded. The parameter must be an identifier for the resource type: ClusterComputeResource. |

**Returns:** `com_vmware_vcenter_namespace__management_software_clusters_info`

---

#### `upgrade_multiple`
Upgrade a set of clusters to its corresponding specific version. if you do not have all of the privileges described as follows: - Operation execution requires System.Anonymous.

**Parameters:**
| Name | Type | Description |
| :--- | :--- | :--- |
| `specs` | `Properties` | Specifications for upgrading selected clusters. The key in the parameter map must be an identifier for the resource type: ClusterComputeResource. |

**Returns:** `Properties`

---

**Returns:** `Array/com_vmware_vcenter_namespace__management_software_clusters_summary`

## com_vmware_vcenter_namespace__management_support__bundle

**Description:** The SupportBundle service provides operations to retrieve the cluster's Namespaces-related support bundle download location.

### Methods

#### `com_vmware_vcenter_namespace__management_support__bundle`
Auto-generated constructor

**Parameters:**
| Name | Type | Description |
| :--- | :--- | :--- |
| `client` | `VAPIClient` | vAPI client |

**Returns:** `void`

---

#### `create`
Returns the location SupportBundle.Location information for downloading the Namespaces-related support bundle for the specified cluster. Retrieving a support bundle involves two steps: - Step 1: Invoke operation to provision a token and a URI. - Step 2: Make an HTTP GET request using URI and one time used token returned in step 1 to generate the support bundle and return it. There can only be one valid token per cluster at any given time. If this operation is invoked again for the same cluster identifier while a token still valid, the API will return the same SupportBundle.Location response. The HTTP GET request will: - return 401 (Not Authorized) if the download URL is recognized, but the token is invalid. - otherwise return 200 (OK), mark the token used (invalidating it for any future use), open a application/tar download stream for the client, and start the bundle process. As part of its work, the API will orchestrate support bundling on the worker nodes of a cluster. If a failure occurs during the collection of support bundle from worker node, the API will not abort the request, but will log a warning and move on to processing other worker nodes' bundles. The API will only abort its operation if the content of the stream has been corrupted. When the API has to abort its operation (and the response stream), it will not provide any indication of failures to the client. The client will need to verify validity of the resultant file based on the format specified in the response's Content-Disposition header. if you do not have all of the privileges described as follows: - Operation execution requires Global.Diagnostics.

**Parameters:**
| Name | Type | Description |
| :--- | :--- | :--- |
| `cluster` | `string` | Identifier of cluster for which the Namespaces-related support bundle should be generated. The parameter must be an identifier for the resource type: ClusterComputeResource. |

**Returns:** `com_vmware_vcenter_namespace__management_support__bundle_location`

---

#### `activate`
Activate Namespace Self Service on the cluster on which vSphere Namespaces enabled. This operation empowers Dev Users/Groups as self-service namespace users to create Supervisor Namespaces through kubectl create namespace command. activate requires the availability of one or more templates in the system. if you do not have all of the privileges described as follows: - The resource ClusterComputeResource referenced by the parameter cluster requires Namespaces.SelfServiceManage.

**Returns:** `Array/com_vmware_vcenter_namespaces_namespace__self__service_summary`

---

#### `deactivate`
Deactivate Namespace Self Service on the cluster on which vSphere Namespaces enabled. This operation reverses Dev Users/Group's self-service namespace capability on the cluster. if you do not have all of the privileges described as follows: - The resource ClusterComputeResource referenced by the parameter cluster requires Namespaces.SelfServiceManage.

**Parameters:**
| Name | Type | Description |
| :--- | :--- | :--- |
| `cluster` | `string` | Identifier for the cluster for which vSphere Namespaces will be disabled. The parameter must be an identifier for the resource type: ClusterComputeResource. |

**Returns:** `void`

---

#### `activate_with_template`
Activate Namespace Self Service on the cluster after configuring namespace template. This is another variant of activate except configures template before activation. The template configuration includes either creating a new template or updating the existing template, depending on the template's existence. Here is supported the flow of actions using the activateWithTemplate call: 1. Activate with the new template using activateWithTemplate call. 2. Deactivate using deactivate call. 3. Active with updating the existing template using activateWithTemplate.

**Parameters:**

## com_vmware_vcenter_ovf_ip__allocation__params

**Description:** The {@name IpAllocationParams} {@term structure} specifies how IP addresses are allocated to OVF properties. In particular, it informs the deployment platform whether the guest supports IPv4, IPv6, or both. It also specifies whether the IP addresses can be obtained through DHCP or through the properties provided in the OVF environment.

Ovf Property elements are exposed to the guest software through the OVF environment. Each Property element exposed in the OVF environment shall be constructed from the value of the ovf:key attribute. A Property element contains a key/value pair, it may optionally specify type qualifiers using the ovf:qualifiers attribute with multiple qualifiers separated by commas.

The settings in {@name IpAllocationParams} {@term structure} are global to a deployment. Thus, if a virtual machine is part of a virtual appliance, then its settings are ignored and the settings for the virtual appliance is used.

This information is based on the vmw:IpAssignmentSection in OVF package.

See {@link LibraryItem#deploy} and {@link LibraryItem#filter}.

### Attributes

| Name | Description | Type | Read-only |
| :--- | :--- | :--- | :--- |
| `supported_allocation_scheme` | Specifies the IP allocation schemes supported by the guest software. This {@term field} defines the valid values for the IP allocation policy. This setting is often configured by the virtual appliance template author or OVF package author to reflect what the guest software supports, and the IP allocation policy is configured at deployment time. See {@link #ipAllocationPolicy}. | `Array/com_vmware_vcenter_ovf_ip__allocation__params_ip__allocation__scheme` | No |
| `supported_ip_allocation_policy` | Specifies the IP allocation policies supported. The set of valid options for the policy is based on the capabilities of the virtual appliance software, as specified by the {@link #supportedAllocationScheme} {@term field}. | `Array/com_vmware_vcenter_ovf_ip__allocation__params_ip__allocation__policy` | No |
| `ip_allocation_policy` | Specifies how IP allocation is done through an IP Pool. This is typically specified by the deployer. | `com_vmware_vcenter_ovf_ip__allocation__params_ip__allocation__policy` | No |
| `supported_ip_protocol` | Specifies the IP protocols supported by the guest. | `Array/com_vmware_vcenter_ovf_ip__allocation__params_ip__protocol` | No |
| `ip_protocol` | Specifies the chosen IP protocol for this deployment. This must be one of the IP protocols supported by the guest software. See {@link #supportedIpProtocol}. | `com_vmware_vcenter_ovf_ip__allocation__params_ip__protocol` | No |
| `type` | Unique identifier describing the type of the OVF parameters. The value is the name of the OVF parameters {@term structure}. | `string` | No |

## com_vmware_vcenter_ovf_ip__allocation__params_ip__allocation__policy

**Description:** The {@name IpAllocationPolicy} {@term enumerated type} defines the possible IP allocation policy for a deployment.

### Attributes

| Name | Description | Type | Read-only |
| :--- | :--- | :--- | :--- |
| `DHCP` | Specifies that DHCP will be used to allocate IP addresses. | `string` | No |
| `TRANSIENT_IPPOOL` | Specifies that IP addresses are allocated from an IP pool. The IP addresses are allocated when needed, typically at power-on, and deallocated during power-off. There is no guarantee that a property will receive same IP address when restarted. | `string` | No |
| `STATIC_MANUAL` | Specifies that IP addresses are configured manually upon deployment, and will be kept until reconfigured or the virtual appliance destroyed. This ensures that a property gets a consistent IP for its lifetime. | `string` | No |
| `STATIC_IPPOOL` | Specifies that IP addresses are allocated from the range managed by an IP pool. The IP addresses are allocated at first power-on, and remain allocated at power-off. This ensures that a virtual appliance gets a consistent IP for its life-time. | `string` | No |

## com_vmware_vcenter_ovf_library__item

**Description:** The {@name LibraryItem} {@term service} provides {@term operations} to deploy virtual machines and virtual appliances from library items containing Open Virtualization Format (OVF) packages in content library, as well as {@term operations} to create library items in content library from virtual machines and virtual appliances.

To deploy a virtual machine or a virtual appliance from a library item:

Create a {@link LibraryItem.DeploymentTarget} to specify the target deployment type and target deployment designation.
Create a {@link LibraryItem.ResourcePoolDeploymentSpec} to specify the parameters for the target deployment.
Use the {@name #deploy} {@term operation} with the created target and parameter specifications, along with the identifier of the specified source content library item. See {@link #deploy}.

To create a library item in content library from a virtual machine or virtual appliance:

Create a {@link LibraryItem.DeployableIdentity} to specify the source virtual machine or virtual appliance to be used as the OVF template source.
Create a {@link LibraryItem.CreateTarget} to specify the target library and library item.
Create a {@link LibraryItem.CreateSpec} to specify the settings for the OVF package to be created.
Use the {@name #create} {@term operation} with the created target and parameter specifications, along with the specified source entity. See {@link #create}.

Creates a library item in content library from a virtual machine or virtual appliance.

This {@term operation} creates a library item in content library whose content is an OVF package derived from a source virtual machine or virtual appliance, using the supplied create specification. The OVF package may be stored as in a newly created library item or in an in an existing library item. For an existing library item whose content is updated by this {@term operation}, the original content is overwritten.

| Name | Type | Description |
| :--- | :--- | :--- |
| `client_token` | `string` | Client-generated token used to retry a request if the client fails to get a response from the server. If the original request succeeded, the result of that request will be returned, otherwise the operation will be retried. |
| `source` | `com_vmware_vcenter_ovf_library__item_deployable__identity` | Identifier of the virtual machine or virtual appliance to use as the source. |
| `target` | `com_vmware_vcenter_ovf_library__item_create__target` | Specification of the target content library and library item. |
| `create_spec` | `com_vmware_vcenter_ovf_library__item_create__spec` | Information used to create the OVF package from the source virtual machine or virtual appliance. |

**Returns:** `com_vmware_vcenter_ovf_library__item_create__result`

---

#### `deploy`
Deploys an OVF package stored in content library to a newly created virtual machine or virtual appliance.

This {@term operation} deploys an OVF package which is stored in the library item specified by {@param.name ovfLibraryItemId}. It uses the deployment specification in {@param.name deploymentSpec} to deploy the OVF package to the location specified by {@param.name target}.

**Parameters:**
| Name | Type | Description |
| :--- | :--- | :--- |
| `client_token` | `string` | Client-generated token used to retry a request if the client fails to get a response from the server. If the original request succeeded, the result of that request will be returned, otherwise the operation will be retried. |
| `ovf_library_item_id` | `string` | Identifier of the content library item containing the OVF package to be deployed. |
| `target` | `com_vmware_vcenter_ovf_library__item_deployment__target` | Specification of the deployment target. |
| `deployment_spec` | `com_vmware_vcenter_ovf_library__item_resource__pool__deployment__spec` | Specification of how the OVF package should be deployed to the target. |

**Returns:** `com_vmware_vcenter_ovf_library__item_deployment__result`

---

## com_vmware_vcenter_ovf_ovf__file__info

**Description:** The {@name OvfFileInfo} {@term structure} contains the information regarding a single file in an OVF package or an OVA package file.

### Attributes

| Name | Description | Type | Read-only |
| :--- | :--- | :--- | :--- |
| `name` | Name of the file.

For files in the file reference section of the OVF this is the name defined in that section. For OVF descriptor, manifest or certificate files the server will assign a name.

If {@link #fileType} is {@name FileType#OVA}, this is will be an assigned name indicating the content that will be transferred from the OVA package file. For example, descriptor.ova refers to the OVF descriptor in the OVA file, message-bundle.ova refers to the message bundle files in the OVA file, disk-content.ova refers to all the disk content in the OVA file. | `string` | No |
| `file_type` | The type of file. | `com_vmware_vcenter_ovf_ovf__file__info_file__type` | No |
| `optional_upload` | Indicates whether the file has to be supplied by the client. If this is a PUSH import, this {@term field} will be false if the client must upload the file to the URL specified in {@link #fileUrl}, and true if the client is not required to upload the file. If this is a PULL import or export, this field can be ignored. | `boolean` | No |
| `file_url` | The location of the file.

When the OVF package is being imported by the client pushing files to the server (see {@link Import#SourceType#PUSH_SOURCE}) this is the URL that the client must upload to. If {@link ImportSession#externalTransferSupported} is true, the URL may be from external service. When the OVF package is being imported by the server pulling files (see {@link Import #SourceType#PULL_SOURCE}) this is the URL that the server will download from.

When this is an OVF package export, then it is the URL that the client is downloading from. For certain file types, such as FileType.MANIFEST, this URL will be unset until the file is ready for download. | `string` | No |
| `ssl_thumb_print` | The SSL thumb print that is for the {@link OvfFileInfo #fileUrl} if required by it. | `string` | No |
| `upload_method` | The HTTP method that can be used to upload file to the {@link OvfFileInfo #fileUrl} if it is an HTTP URL, PUT method should be used if it is unset. | `com_vmware_vcenter_ovf_ovf__file__info_http__upload__method` | No |
| `size` | The size of the file in bytes. This is the number of bytes to be transferred, which might not be the same as the logical size of the object represented by the underlying file.

It might not be known until the complete file has been transferred. In that case, the {@term field} is {@term unset}.

If {@link #fileType} is {@name FileType#OVA}, the size will be the total size of the files that are actually transferred from the OVA file. The transferred content are different at different {@name ImportSession#State}. | `number` | No |
| `bytes_transferred` | The number of transferred bytes.

When the file transfer is complete {@name #bytesTransferred} will be equal to {@link #size}..

If {@link #fileType} is {@name FileType#OVA}, the transferred bytes will be the total transferred bytes of the files that are actually transferred from the OVA file. | `number` | No |
| `sha256` | SHA-256 hash of the file contents. | `string` | No |

## com_vmware_vcenter_ovf_ovf__params

**Description:** The {@name OvfParams} {@term structure} defines the common {@term fields} for all OVF deployment parameters. OVF parameters serve several purposes:
Describe information about a given OVF package.
Describe default deployment configuration.
Describe possible deployment values based on the deployment environment.
Provide deployment-specific configuration.
Each OVF parameters {@term structure} specifies a particular configurable aspect of OVF deployment. An aspect has both a query-model and a deploy-model. The query-model is used when the OVF package is queried, and the deploy-model is used when deploying an OVF package.

Most OVF parameter {@term structures} provide both informational and deployment parameters. However, some are purely informational (for example, download size) and some are purely deployment parameters (for example, the flag to indicate whether registration as a vCenter extension is accepted).

See {@link LibraryItem#deploy} and {@link LibraryItem#filter}.

### Attributes

| Name | Description | Type | Read-only |
| :--- | :--- | :--- | :--- |
| `type` | Unique identifier describing the type of the OVF parameters. The value is the name of the OVF parameters {@term structure}. | `string` | No |

## com_vmware_vcenter_ovf_parse__issue_category

**Description:** The {@name Category} {@term enumerated type} defines the categories of issues that can be found when parsing files inside an OVF package (see {@link ParseIssue}) including OVF descriptor (which is an XML document), manifest and certificate files, or exporting an OVF package.

### Attributes

| Name | Description | Type | Read-only |
| :--- | :--- | :--- | :--- |
| `VALUE_ILLEGAL` | Illegal value error. For example, the value is malformed, not a number, or outside of the given range, and so on. | `string` | No |
| `ATTRIBUTE_REQUIRED` | Required attribute error. It indicates that a required attribute is missing from an element in the OVF descriptor. | `string` | No |
| `ATTRIBUTE_ILLEGAL` | Illegal attribute error. It indicates that an illegal attribute is set for an element in the OVF descriptor. For example, empty disks do not use format, parentRef, and populatedSize attributes, if these attributes are present in an empty disk element then will get this pasrse issue. | `string` | No |
| `ELEMENT_REQUIRED` | Required element error. It indicates that a required element is missing from the OVF descriptor. | `string` | No |
| `ELEMENT_ILLEGAL` | Illegal element error. It indicates that an element is present in a location which is not allowed, or found multiple elements but only one is allowed at the location in the OVF descriptor. | `string` | No |
| `ELEMENT_UNKNOWN` | Unknown element error. It indicates that an element is unsupported when parsing an OVF descriptor. | `string` | No |
| `SECTION_UNKNOWN` | Section unknown error. It indicates that a section is unsupported when parsing an OVF descriptor. | `string` | No |
| `SECTION_RESTRICTION` | Section restriction error. It indicates that a section appears in place in the OVF descriptor where it is not allowed, a section appears fewer times than is required, or a section appears more times than is allowed. | `string` | No |
| `PARSE_ERROR` | OVF package parsing error, including:
OVF descriptor parsing errors, for example, syntax errors or schema errors.
Manifest file parsing and verification errors.
Certificate file parsing and verification errors. | `string` | No |
| `GENERATE_ERROR` | OVF descriptor (which is an XML document) generating error, for example, well-formedness errors as well as unexpected processing conditions. | `string` | No |
| `VALIDATION_ERROR` | An issue with the manifest and signing. | `string` | No |
| `EXPORT_ERROR` | Issue during OVF export, for example, malformed deviceId, controller not found, or file backing for a device not found. | `string` | No |
| `INTERNAL_ERROR` | Server encountered an unexpected error which prevented it from fulfilling the request. | `string` | No |

## com_vmware_vcenter_ovf_property

**Description:** The {@name Property} {@term structure} contains the information about a property in an OVF package.

A property is uniquely identified by its [classid.]id[.instanceid] fully-qualified name (see {@link #classId}, {@link #id}, and {@link #instanceId}). If multiple properties in an OVF package have the same fully-qualified name, then the property is excluded and cannot be set. We do warn about this during import.

See {@link LibraryItem#deploy} and {@link LibraryItem#filter}.

### Attributes

| Name | Description | Type | Read-only |
| :--- | :--- | :--- | :--- |
| `class_id` | The classId of this OVF property. | `string` | No |
| `id` | The identifier of this OVF property. | `string` | No |
| `instance_id` | The instanceId of this OVF property. | `string` | No |
| `category` | If this is set to a non-empty string, this property starts a new category. | `string` | No |
| `ui_optional` | Whether a category is UI optional. This is only used if this property starts a new category (see {@link #category}).

The value is stored in an optional attribute vmw:uioptional to the ovf:Category element. The default value is false. If this value is true, the properties within this category are optional. The UI renders this as a group with a check box, and the group is grayed out until the check box is selected. When the check box is selected, the input values are read and used in deployment. If properties within the same category specify conflicting values the default is used. Only implemented in vSphere Web Client 5.1 and later as of Nov 2012. | `boolean` | No |
| `label` | The display name of this OVF property. | `string` | No |
| `description` | A description of this OVF property. | `string` | No |
| `type` | The type of this OVF property. Refer to the configuration of a virtual appliance/virtual machine for the valid values. | `string` | No |
| `value` | The OVF property value. This contains the default value from ovf:defaultValue if ovf:value is not present when read. | `string` | No |

## com_vmware_vcenter_resource__pool

This {@term service} does not include virtual appliances in the inventory of resource pools even though part of the behavior of a virtual appliance is to act like a resource pool.

#### `com_vmware_vcenter_resource__pool`
Auto-generated constructor

**Parameters:**
| Name | Type | Description |
| :--- | :--- | :--- |
| `client` | `VAPIClient` | vAPI client |

**Returns:** `void`

---

If unset or empty, ResourcePool.ResourceAllocationCreateSpec.limit will be set to -1. | `number` | No |

If unset or empty, ResourcePool.ResourceAllocationUpdateSpec.limit will be set to -1. | `number` | No |

## com_vmware_vcenter_resource__pool_shares__info

**Description:** The ResourcePool.SharesInfo structure provides specification of shares. Shares are used to determine relative allocation between resource consumers. In general, a consumer with more shares gets proportionally more of the resource, subject to certain other constraints.

### Attributes

| Name | Description | Type | Read-only |
| :--- | :--- | :--- | :--- |
| `level` | The allocation level. It maps to a pre-determined set of numeric values for shares. If the shares value does not map to a predefined size, then the level is set as CUSTOM. | `com_vmware_vcenter_resource__pool_shares__info_level` | No |
| `shares` | When ResourcePool.SharesInfo.level is set to CUSTOM, it is the number of shares allocated. Otherwise, this value is ignored. There is no unit for this value. It is a relative measure based on the settings for other resource pools. This field is optional and it is only relevant when the value of ResourcePool.SharesInfo.level is CUSTOM. | `number` | No |

## com_vmware_vcenter_resource__pool_shares__info_level

**Description:** The ResourcePool.SharesInfo.Level enumerated type defines the possible values for the allocation level.

| Name | Description | Type | Read-only |
| :--- | :--- | :--- | :--- |

The last status only reports on the state of the iteration at the time data was last returned. As a result, it not does guarantee if the next call will succeed in getting more data or not. Failures to retrieve results will be returned as Error responses. These last statuses are only returned when the iterator is operating as expected.

### Attributes

| Name | Description | Type | Read-only |
| :--- | :--- | :--- | :--- |
| `READY` | Iterator has more data pending and is ready to provide it. The caller can request the next page of data at any time. The number of results returned may be less than the usual size. In other words, the iterator may not fill the page. The iterator has returned at least 1 result. | `string` | No |
| `END_OF_DATA` | Iterator has finished iterating through its inventory. There are currently no more entities to return and the caller can terminate iteration. If the iterator returned some data, the marker may be set to allow the iterator to continue from where it left off when additional data does become available. This value is used to indicate that all available data has been returned by the iterator. | `string` | No |

## com_vmware_vcenter_tokenservice_error

**Description:** The {@name Error} {@term error} describes the{@term fields} common to all standard {@term errors}.

This {@term error} serves two purposes:

It is the {@term error} that clients in many programming languages can catch to handle all standard {@term errors}. Typically those clients will display one or more of the localizable messages from {@link #messages} to a human.
It is the {@term error} that {@term operations} can report when they need to report some {@term error}, but the {@term error} doesn't fit into any other standard {@term error}, and in fact the only reasonable way for a client to react to the {@term error} is to display the message(s) to a human.

### Attributes

| Name | Description | Type | Read-only |
| :--- | :--- | :--- | :--- |
| `messages` | Stack of one or more localizable messages for human {@term error} consumers.

The message at the top of the stack (first in the list) describes the {@term error} from the perspective of the {@term operation} the client invoked. Each subsequent message in the stack describes the "cause" of the prior message. | `Array/com_vmware_vapi_std_localizable__message` | No |
| `data` | Data to facilitate clients responding to the {@term operation} reporting a standard {@term error} to indicating that it was unable to complete successfully.

{@term Operations} may provide data that clients can use when responding to {@term errors}. Since the data that clients need may be specific to the context of the {@term operation} reporting the {@term error}, different {@term operations} that report the same {@term error} may provide different data in the {@term error}. The documentation for each each {@term operation} will describe what, if any, data it provides for each {@term error} it reports. The {@link ArgumentLocations}, {@link FileLocations}, and {@link TransientIndication} {@term structures} are intended as possible values for this {@term field}. {@link com.vmware.vapi.std.DynamicID} may also be useful as a value for this {@term field} (although that is not its primary purpose). Some {@term services} may provide their own specific {@term structures} for use as the value of this {@term field} when reporting {@term errors} from their {@term operations}. | `DynamicStructure` | No |

## com_vmware_vcenter_trusted__infrastructure_trust__authority__clusters_attestation_tpm2_endorsement__keys_create__spec

**Description:** The EndorsementKeys.CreateSpec structure contains information that describes a TPM endorsement key. Only one of EndorsementKeys.CreateSpec.public-key or EndorsementKeys.CreateSpec.certificate must be specified.

### Attributes

| Name | Description | Type | Read-only |
| :--- | :--- | :--- | :--- |
| `name` | A unique name for the TPM endorsement key. The unique name should be something that an administrator can use to easily identify the remote system. For example, the hostname, or hardware UUID. When clients pass a value of this structure as a parameter, the field must be an identifier for the resource type: com.vmware.vcenter.trusted_infrastructure.trust_authority_clusters.attestation.tpm2.EndorsementKey. When operations return a value of this structure as a result, the field will be an identifier for the resource type: com.vmware.vcenter.trusted_infrastructure.trust_authority_clusters.attestation.tpm2.EndorsementKey. | `string` | No |
| `public_key` | TPM public endorsement key in PEM format. If unset EndorsementKeys.CreateSpec.certificate must be set. | `string` | No |
| `certificate` | TPM endorsement key certificate in PEM format. When a endorsement key certificate is provided, it will be verified against the CA certificate list. Endorsement key certificates that are not signed by one of the CA certificates will be rejected. Using this format allows for failures to be caught during configuration rather than later during attestation. If unset EndorsementKeys.CreateSpec.public-key must be set. | `string` | No |

#### `list$task`
Return the remote server certificates. Contacts the configured key servers and attempts to retrieve their certificates. These certificates might not yet be trusted. If the returned certificates are to be considered trustworthy, then it must be added to the list of trusted server certificates by adding to the certificates returned by TrustedPeerCertificates.get and invoking TrustedPeerCertificates.update with the updated list of certificates.

## com_vmware_vcenter_trusted__infrastructure_trusted__clusters_attestation_services__applied__config

**Description:** The ServicesAppliedConfig service provides information about the aggregate health of the applied Attestation Service configuration on the Trusted Clusters. The desired state of the Attestation Service is stored within vCenter, while the applied configuration is stored on the hosts in the cluster. The ServicesAppliedConfig service is available for all clusters, not only Trusted Clusters. In such cases empty desired state is assumed, e.g. when an applied Attestation Service configuration is found outside of a Trusted Cluster it is considered an ERROR. The ServicesAppliedConfig service is able to put the applied Attestation Service configuration into a consistent state when individual host configurations have diverged from the desired state.

### Methods

#### `com_vmware_vcenter_trusted__infrastructure_trusted__clusters_attestation_services__applied__config`
Auto-generated constructor

| Name | Type | Description |
| :--- | :--- | :--- |
| `client` | `VAPIClient` | vAPI client |

**Returns:** `void`

---

#### `list$task`
Returns basic information about the health of all Attestation Service configurations applied to the cluster with respect to the desired state.

**Parameters:**
| Name | Type | Description |
| :--- | :--- | :--- |
| `cluster` | `string` | The ID of the cluster against which the operation will be executed. The parameter must be an identifier for the resource type: ClusterComputeResource. |

**Returns:** `string`

---

**Parameters:**
| Name | Type | Description |
| :--- | :--- | :--- |
| `cluster` | `string` | The ID of the cluster against which the operation will be executed. The parameter must be an identifier for the resource type: ClusterComputeResource. |
| `address` | `com_vmware_vcenter_trusted__infrastructure_network__address` | The network address of the Attestation Service instance. |

**Returns:** `string`

---

#### `update$task`
Update the applied Attestation Service configuration on the given Trusted Cluster to be consistent with the desired state. This method has no affect on the desired state, apart from it being used as a reference point for the remediation.

**Parameters:**
| Name | Type | Description |
| :--- | :--- | :--- |
| `cluster` | `string` | The ID of the Trusted Cluster against which the operation will be executed. The parameter must be an identifier for the resource type: ClusterComputeResource. |

**Returns:** `string`

---

#### `delete$task`
Delete the Attestation Service configuration that has been applied to the given cluster. This method has no affect on the desired state, it only removes applied Attestation Service configuration from any Trusted Hosts within the given cluster.

| :--- | :--- | :--- |

## com_vmware_vcenter_vcha_cluster

**Description:** The {@name Cluster} {@term service} provides {@term operations} to deploy and undeploy a vCenter High Availability (VCHA) cluster, failover from the active VCHA node to the passive VCHA node, and retrieve the status of the VCHA cluster.

### Methods

#### `com_vmware_vcenter_vcha_cluster`
Auto-generated constructor

**Parameters:**
| Name | Type | Description |
| :--- | :--- | :--- |
| `client` | `VAPIClient` | vAPI client |

**Returns:** `void`

---

#### `failover$task`
Initiates failover from the active vCenter node to the passive node.

For forced failover, Active node immediately initiates a failover. This may result into a data loss after failover.

For planned failover, Active node flushes all the state to the Passive node, waits for the flush to complete before causing a failover. After the failover, Passive node starts without any data loss.

A failover is allowed only in the following cases:

Cluster's mode is enabled and all cluster members are present.
Cluster's mode is maintenance and all cluster members are present.

**Parameters:**
| Name | Type | Description |
| :--- | :--- | :--- |
| `planned` | `boolean` | If false, a failover is initiated immediately and may result in data loss.<br> If true, a failover is initated after the Active node flushes its state to Passive and there is no data loss. |

**Returns:** `string`

---

#### `get`
Retrieves the status of a VCHA cluster.

**Parameters:**
| Name | Type | Description |
| :--- | :--- | :--- |
| `vc_spec` | `com_vmware_vcenter_vcha_credentials__spec` | Contains active node's management vCenter server credentials. |
| `partial` | `boolean` | If true, then return only the information that does not require connecting to the Active vCenter Server.<br> If false or unset, then return all the information. |

**Returns:** `com_vmware_vcenter_vcha_cluster_info`

---

#### `deploy$task`
Prepares, clones, and configures a VCHA cluster.

**Parameters:**
| Name | Type | Description |
| :--- | :--- | :--- |
| `spec` | `com_vmware_vcenter_vcha_cluster_deploy__spec` | Contains the deploy specification for all three nodes of a VCHA cluster. |

**Returns:** `string`

---

#### `undeploy$task`
Destroys the VCHA cluster and removes all VCHA specific information from the VCVA appliance. Optionally, the passive and witness node virtual machines will be deleted only if VCHA was deployed using automatic deployment. The active node in the cluster continues to run as a standalone VCVA appliance after the destroy operation has been performed.

If the VCHA cluster is in a transition state and not configured, then the VCHA cluster specific information is removed.

**Parameters:**
| Name | Type | Description |
| :--- | :--- | :--- |
| `spec` | `com_vmware_vcenter_vcha_cluster_undeploy__spec` | Contains the undeploy specification for a VCHA cluster. |

**Returns:** `string`

---

## com_vmware_vcenter_vcha_cluster_mode

**Description:** The {@term Mode} {@term service} provides {@term operations} to manage the operating mode of a vCenter High Availability Cluster (VCHA Cluster).

### Methods

#### `com_vmware_vcenter_vcha_cluster_mode`
Auto-generated constructor

**Parameters:**
| Name | Type | Description |
| :--- | :--- | :--- |
| `client` | `VAPIClient` | vAPI client |

**Returns:** `void`

---

#### `get`
Retrieves the current mode of a VCHA cluster.

**Returns:** `com_vmware_vcenter_vcha_cluster_mode_info`

---

#### `set$task`
Manipulates the mode of a VCHA Cluster. Following mode transitions are allowed:
enabled -> disabled - Allowed only in healthy and degraded states.
enabled -> maintenance - Allowed only in healthy state.
disabled -> enabled - Allowed only in healthy state.
maintenance -> enabled - Allowed only in healthy state with all nodes are running the same version.
maintenance -> disabled - Allowed only in healthy state with all nodes are running the same version.
All other transitions are not allowed.

VCHA Cluster configuration remains intact in any of the cluster modes.

**Parameters:**
| Name | Type | Description |
| :--- | :--- | :--- |
| `mode` | `com_vmware_vcenter_vcha_cluster_mode_cluster__mode` | Clustermode to change the VCHA cluster mode to. |

**Returns:** `string`

---

| `force_delete` | Flag controlling in what circumstances the virtual machines will be deleted. For this flag to take effect, the VCHA cluster should have been successfully configured using automatic deployment.

If the {@link #forceDelete} {@term field} is true, then this information is ignored, VCHA cluster specific information is removed and the passive and witness virtual machines will be deleted.
If the {@link #forceDelete} {@term field} is {@term unset} or false, then this information is validated prior to deleting the passive and witness virtual machines. VCHA cluster specific information is removed. | `com_vmware_vcenter_vcha_cluster_vm__info` | No |

## com_vmware_vcenter_vdcs_delta__disk__spec

**Description:** The {@name DeltaDiskSpec} {@term structure} describes specification related to a delta disk.

A delta disk is a way to preserve a virtual disk at some point in time. A delta disk is a file which in turn points to the original virtual disk file (the parent). After a delta disk is added, all writes go to the delta disk. All reads first try the delta disk and then try the parent if needed.

A delta disk can be added to a disk either implicitly during snapshot operations, or explicitly during creation or update of the virtual machine.

Note that the type of the disk is consistent throughout the chain; any new delta disk which is added is of the same type as the original disk . Also note that since the parent disk is not being written to, it is possible that the parent disk may be shared among multiple disks belonging to multiple virtual machines.

### Attributes

| Name | Description | Type | Read-only |
| :--- | :--- | :--- | :--- |
| `parent_file_id` | Identifier which identifies the parent disk file of this virtual disk file.

{@link com.vmware.vapi.std.DynamicID#type} is the value of {@link #VMDK_DISK_TYPE} and {@link com.vmware.vapi.std.DynamicID#id} is the value for this type of resource.

For example:

{@code parentFileId.type="com.vmware.vcenter.storage.DatastoreFile"}
{@code parentFileId.id="[ds-25]5240b16d-d66ffc79-7f41-00505691c32c/win8/win8.vmdk"}

During virtual machine creation and update this property is only checked if a new disk is added. In this case, a new delta disk is created which points to the parent disk. The parent disk is assumed to exist and will not be recursively created. | `com_vmware_vapi_std_dynamic__ID` | No |
| `format` | The format of the delta disk. | `com_vmware_vcenter_vdcs_delta__disk__spec_format` | No |

## com_vmware_vcenter_vdcs_ip__assignment

**Description:** The {@name IpAssignment} {@term structure} specifies how the guest operating system is configured with IP addresses, including protocol type (IPv4 or IPv6) and whether the assignment should be software driven (DHCP) or allocated by the system and passed into the guest.

The guest operating system can be configured to support DHCP, OVF assigned IP configuration, or both. The {@link #supportedAllocationScheme} {@term field} lists the supported schemes.

The {@name IpAssignment} settings are global to a deployment. Thus, if a virtual machine is part of a virtual appliance, then its settings are ignored and the settings for the virtual appliance are used.

### Attributes

| Name | Description | Type | Read-only |
| :--- | :--- | :--- | :--- |
| `supported_allocation_scheme` | Specifies the IP allocation schemes supported by the guest operating system. This {@term field} defines what the valid values are for {@link #ipAllocationPolicy}. This setting is often configured by the virtual appliance template author or OVF package author to reflect what the guest operating system supports, and the {@link #ipAllocationPolicy} is configured at deployment time.

The below table describes what IP allocation policies are supported for a given IP allocation scheme.

IP Allocation Scheme	IP Allocation Policy
DHCP	DHCP
OVF_ENVIRONMENT	TRANSIENT, FIXED, FIXED_ALLOCATED | `DHCP` | DHCP |
| `ip_allocation_policy` | Specifies how IP allocation is done for this virtual appliance. This is typically specified by the deployer of the virtual appliance. The set of valid options for the policy is based on the capabilities of the virtual appliance software, as specified by the {@link #supportedAllocationScheme} {@term field}. | `com_vmware_vcenter_vdcs_ip__assignment_ip__allocation__policy` | No |
| `supported_ip_protocol` | Specifies the IP protocols supported by the guest software. This {@term field} is often configured by the virtual appliance template author or OVF package author to describe what IP protocols are supported by the virtual appliance's virtual machines.
The specific IP protocol for a virtual appliance is set via the {@link #ipProtocol} {@term field} by the deployer of the virtual appliance. | `Array/com_vmware_vcenter_vdcs_ip__assignment_protocol` | No |
| `ip_protocol` | Specifies the chosen IP protocol for this deployment. This must be one of the values in the {@link #supportedIpProtocol} {@term field}. | `com_vmware_vcenter_vdcs_ip__assignment_protocol` | No |

## com_vmware_vcenter_vdcs_ip__assignment_ip__allocation__policy

**Description:** The {@name IpAllocationPolicy} {@term enumerated type} defines IP allocation policies for a deployment.

### Attributes

| Name | Description | Type | Read-only |
| :--- | :--- | :--- | :--- |
| `DHCP` | Specifies that DHCP must be used to allocate IP addresses. | `string` | No |
| `TRANSIENT` | Specifies that IP allocation is allocated through an IP pool. The IP addresses are allocated when needed, typically at power-on, and deallocated during power-off. There is no guarantee that a property will receive the same IP address when restarted. | `string` | No |
| `FIXED` | Specifies that IP addresses are configured manually upon deployment, and will be kept until reconfigured or the virtual appliance is destroyed. This will ensure that a property gets a consistent IP for its lifetime. | `string` | No |
| `FIXED_ALLOCATED` | Specifies that IP allocation is done through the range managed by an IP pool. The IP addresses are allocated at first power-on, and remain allocated at power-off. This will ensure that a virtual appliance gets a consistent IP for its lifetime. | `string` | No |

## com_vmware_vcenter_vdcs_memory__resource__allocation

**Description:** The {@name MemoryResourceAllocation} {@term structure} specifies the reserved resource requirement as well as the limit (maximum allowed usage) for a virtual machine's memory, specified in MB.

If the limit is configured, it must be greater than or equal to the reservation.

### Attributes

| Name | Description | Type | Read-only |
| :--- | :--- | :--- | :--- |
| `limit` | The utilization of a virtual machine will not exceed this limit, even if there are available resources. This is typically used to ensure consistent performance of virtual machines independent of available resources. Units are in MB. | `number` | No |
| `reservation` | Amount of resource that is guaranteed available to the virtual machine. Reserved resources are not wasted if they are not used. If the utilization is less than the reservation, the resources can be utilized by other running virtual machines. Units are in MB. | `number` | No |
| `shares` | Shares are used to determine relative allocation between resource consumers. In general, a consumer with more shares gets proportionally more of the resource, subject to certain other constraints. Memory shares are used in case of resource contention. | `com_vmware_vcenter_vdcs_shares__info` | No |

## com_vmware_vcenter_vdcs_property__spec

**Description:** The {@name PropertySpec} {@term structure} describes information about a property.

A property is uniquely identified with its {@code [classId].[id].[instanceId]} fully- qualified name.

### Attributes

| Name | Description | Type | Read-only |
| :--- | :--- | :--- | :--- |
| `class_id` | Class identifier for this property.

This field combined with the {@link #id} and {@link #instanceId} fields uniquely identifies this property. The format of the identifier is of the form: {@code [classId].[id].[instanceId]}.

This is also used to correlate the property to a corresponding product information structure.

Valid values for {@code classId}: Any {@term string} except any whitespace characters. | `string` | No |
| `instance_id` | Instance identifier for this property.

This field combined with the {@link #id} and {@link #classId} fields uniquely identifies this property. The format of the identifier is of the form: {@code [classId].[id].[instanceId]}.

This is also used to correlate the property to a corresponding product information structure.

Valid values for {@code instanceId}: Any {@term string} except any whitespace characters. | `string` | No |
| `id` | Identifier of this property. In the OVF environment, the property is listed as {@code [classId].[id].[instanceId]}. The {@code [classId].[id].[instanceId]} must be unique.

This field cannot be empty for a property. Thus, it must be specified at creation and cannot be set to the empty {@term string}.

Valid values for {@code id}: Any {@term string} except any white-space characters. | `string` | No |
| `category` | If this is set to a non-empty {@term string}, this property starts a new category. If the category is empty, the property is in the same category as the previous item. Previous is based on the value of the order field. | `string` | No |
| `ui_optional` | Whether a category is UI optional. This is only used if this property starts a new category. | `boolean` | No |
| `label` | The display name for the property. | `string` | No |
| `description` | A description of the field. | `string` | No |
| `user_configurable` | Whether the property is user-configurable or a system property. This is not used if the type is expression. | `boolean` | No |
| `type` | Describes the valid format of the property.

A type must be one of:

{@code string} : A generic {@term string}. Max length 65535 (64k).
{@code string(x..)} : A {@term string} with minimum character length {@code x}.
{@code string(..y)} : A {@term string} with maximum character length {@code y}.
{@code string(x..y)} : A {@term string} with minimum character length {@code x} and maximum character length {@code y}.
{@code string["choice1", "choice2", "choice3"]} : A choice between a fixed set of options. The slash character ({@code \}) is used to escape quote ({@code "}) and slash ({@code \}), for example, {@code "start\"middle\"end"} and {@code "start\\end"}.
{@code int} : An integer value. Is semantically equivalent to {@code int(-2147483648..2147483647)}, for example, signed int32.
{@code int(x..y)}: An integer value with a minimum size {@code x} and a maximum size {@code y}. For example {@code int(0..255)} is a number between 0 and 255 both inclusive. This is also a way to specify that the number must be a uint8. There is always a lower and an upper bound. Max number of digits is 100 including any sign. If exported to OVF the value will be truncated to max of uint64 or int64.
{@code real} : IEEE 8-byte floating-point value.
{@code real(x..y)} : IEEE 8-byte floating-point value with a minimum size {@code x} and a maximum size {@code y}. For example {@code real(-1.5..1.5)} must be a number between -1.5 and 1.5. Because of the nature of float, some conversions can truncate the value. Real must be encoded acording to the Common Information Model (CIM) standard:

RealValue = [ "+" | "-" ] *decimalDigit "." 1*decimalDigit [ ("e" | "E" ) [ "+" | "-" ] 1*decimalDigit ] ]

{@code boolean} : A {@term boolean}. The value can be true or false.
{@code password} : A generic {@term string}. Max length 65535 (64k).
{@code password(x..)} : A {@term string} with minimum character length {@code x}.
{@code password(..y)} : A {@term string} with maximum character length {@code y}.
{@code password(x..y)} : A {@term string} with minimum character length {@code x} and maximum character length {@code y}.
{@code ip} : An IPv4 address in dot-decimal notation or an IPv6 address in colon-hexadecimal notation.
{@code ip:network} : An IP address in dot-notation (IPv4) and colon-hexadecimal (IPv6) on a particular network. The behavior of this type depends on the {@link IpAssignment#ipAllocationPolicy}.
{@code expression} : The default value specifies an expression that is calculated by the system. See details below.

For properties of type {@code password}, the value field and default value field will always be returned as an empty {@term string} when queried. Thus, it is a write-only property. Typically, a client application will also render these as a text field with hidden text and double prompting.

An expression follows the general patterns of either {@code ${arg}} or {@code ${cmd:arg}}. The list of supported expressions are listed below:

{@code ${}} : This expression evaluates to the same value as the named property in the parent virtual appliance. A parent virtual appliance is the first virtual appliance in the ancestry chain (resource pools are skipped). If no parent virtual appliance exists or the property is not defined on the parent virtual appliance, the expression evaluates to the empty value.
{@code ${subnet:network}} : The subnet value of the given network.
{@code ${netmask:network}} : The netmask value of the given network.
{@code ${gateway:network}} : The gateway value of the given network.
{@code ${autoIp:network}} : An auto-assigned network address on the given network.
{@code ${net:network}} : The name of the network.
{@code ${domainName:network}} : The DNS domain name, for example, {@code vmware.com}, of the given network.
{@code ${searchPath:network}} : The DNS search path with paths delimited by a semicolon, for example, {@code eng.vmware.com;vmware.com}, of the given network.
{@code ${hostPrefix:network}} : The host prefix on a given network, for example, {@code "voe-"}.
{@code ${dns:network}} : A comma-separated {@term string} of configured network addresses.
{@code ${httpProxy:network}} : The {@code hostname:port} for a proxy on the network.
{@code ${vimIp:}} : The IP address of the VIM API provider server. This would typically be an ESX Server or vCenter Server.

A virtual appliance will fail to start if any of the properties cannot be computed. For example, if a property references a gateway on a network for which no gateway was configured. The computed value is assigned to the {@link #value} field upon start of the virtual appliance or virtual machine. The value is cleared once the virtual appliance or virtual machine is not running.

The system provides three ways of specifying IP addresses:

{@code ip}
{@code ip:network}
{@code ${ip:network}} expression.

The {@code ip} type is typically used to specify an IP addressed to an external system. Thus, these are not used by a virtual ethernet adapter within the guest itself. Both the {@code ip:network} and the {@code ${ip:network}} expressions are intended as a way to obtain an IP address for a virtual machine. | `string` | No |
| `value` | The value of the field at deployment time. For expressions, this will contain the value that has been computed.

Updates of this value are ignored if the type is {@code "expression"}. | `string` | No |

## com_vmware_vcenter_vdcs_rdm__disk__spec

**Description:** The {@name RdmDiskSpec} {@term structure} describes specification for a raw disk mapping (RDM) disk.

The type of the disk is {@link DiskSpec#RDM_DISK_TYPE}. A RDM virtual disk grants access to the entire raw disk.

### Attributes

| Name | Description | Type | Read-only |
| :--- | :--- | :--- | :--- |
| `compatibility_mode` | Compatibility mode of the RDM disk.

Once the disk is created, this cannot be changed. | `com_vmware_vcenter_vdcs_rdm__disk__spec_virtual__disk__compatibility__mode` | No |
| `uuid` | Virtual disk UUID. | `string` | No |
| `change_id` | The change identifier of the virtual disk for the corresponding snapshot or virtual machine. This can be used to track incremental changes to a virtual disk. | `string` | No |
| `content_id` | Content identifier of the virtual disk file, if available.

A content identifier indicates the logical contents of the disk backing and its parents.

This property is only guaranteed to be up to date if this disk backing is not currently being written to by any virtual machine.

The only supported operation is comparing if two content identifiers are equal or not. The guarantee provided by the content identifier is that if two disk backings have the same content identifier and are not currently being written to, then reads issued from the guest operating system to those disk backings will return the same data. | `string` | No |
| `device_name` | The name of the device on the host system that the LUN is being accessed through.

If the target LUN is not available on the host then it is empty. For example, this could happen if it has accidentally been masked out.

It is required for {@link VirtualDiskCompatibilityMode#PHYSICAL} compatibility mode. | `string` | No |
| `lun_uuid` | Unique identifier of the LUN accessed by the raw disk mapping. | `string` | No |
| `resource_type` | Disk type. Supported resource types are as defined in this class. | `string` | No |

## com_vmware_vcenter_vdcs_serial__port__spec_type

**Description:** Serial port backing types.

### Attributes

| Name | Description | Type | Read-only |
| :--- | :--- | :--- | :--- |
| `FILE` | Backing that connects a virtual serial port with a host file. | `string` | No |
| `DEVICE` | Backing that allows a host serial port device to be used as backing for virtual serial port. | `string` | No |
| `URI` | Backing that supports a connection between the virtual machine and a resource on the network. You can use URI backing to create a network serial port on the virtual machine, supporting connections between the virtual machine and remote systems.

When a virtual machine establishes a connection with a remote system on the network, the virtual machine can act as a server or a client. When the virtual machine acts as a server, it accepts a connection. When the virtual machine acts as a client, it initiates the connection.

You can configure the virtual serial port for communication through a virtual serial port concentrator that acts as a proxy between the virtual machine and the network. When you specify a {@link SerialPortSpec#proxyUri}, the virtual machine initiates the connection with the concentrator and forwards the {@link SerialPortSpec#direction} and {@link SerialPortSpec#serviceUri} to the concentrator.

ESX hosts support different protocols depending on your virtual serial port configuration.

If the virtual machine is handling the network connection directly (no {@link SerialPortSpec#proxyUri} specified), you can use telnet, TCP, and SSL protocols. The {@link SerialPortSpec#serviceUri} must use one of the following URI schemes:
{@code :} - this is the equivalent of {@code tcp://:}.
{@code tcp://:} - unencrypted TCP connection (IPv4 or IPv6).
{@code tcp4://:} - unencrypted TCP connection (IPv4 only).
{@code tcp6://:} - unencrypted TCP connection (IPv6 only).
{@code ssl://:} - this is the equivalent of {@code tcp+ssl://:}.
{@code tcp+ssl://:} - encrypted SSL over TCP.
{@code tcp4+ssl://:} - SSL over TCP over IPv4.
{@code tcp6+ssl://:} - SSL over TCP over IPv6.
{@code telnet://:} - telnet over TCP. The virtual
machine and remote system can negotiate and use SSL if the remote system supports the telnet authentication option; if not, the connection uses unencrypted text (plaintext).
{@code telnets://:} - telnet over SSL over TCP. In this case, SSL negotiation begins immediately and you cannot use the telnet authentication option.
You can specify authentication parameters to support an encrypted connection with a remote system using SSL over telnet or telnets. The connection will fail if the peer does not support the protocols. You cannot use certificate verification when you specify {@code tcp}, {@code tcp4}, or {@code tcp6} schemas. For information about parameter specification, see Authentication Parameters below.

If you are using a {@link SerialPortSpec#proxyUri} to connect to a virtual serial port concentrator, the URI scheme for the communication between the remote system on the network and the concentrator depends on the concentrator implementation. The connection between the concentrator and the virtual serial port must use telnet or secure telnet (telnets). The proxy URI must use one of the following URI schemes. You cannot specify a username and password in the proxy URI.
{@code telnet://:}- telnet over TCP. The virtual machine and remote system can negotiate and use SSL if the remote system supports the telnet authentication option; if not, the connection uses unencrypted text (plaintext).
{@code telnets://:} - telnet over SSL over TCP. In this case, SSL negotiation starts immediately and you cannot use the telnet authentication option.
You can specify authentication parameters to support an encrypted connection with a concentrator using SSL over telnet or telnets. The connection will fail if the concentrator does not support the protocols. For information about parameter specification, see Authentication Parameters below.

Authentication Parameters

For an encrypted connection, the URI includes a set of authentication parameters. The parameters are specified as key words or key/value pairs. The following syntax description uses {@code telnet}; you can also specify authentication parameters for secure telnet ({@code telnets}).

{@code telnet://:#key[=value][&key[=value] ...]}

The first parameter must have a number sign ({@code #}) prefix. Additional parameters must have an ampersand ({@code &}) prefix. The following list shows the valid parameters.

{@code thumbprint=value} - Specifies a certificate thumbprint against which the peer certificate thumbprint is compared. When you specify a thumbprint, certificate verification is automatically enabled. See the description of the {@code verify} parameter below.
{@code peerName=value} - Specifies the peer name that will be used to validate the peer certificate. When you specify a peer name, certificate verification is automatically enabled. See the description of the {@code verify} parameter below.
{@code verify} - Forces certificate verification. The virtual machine will verify that the peer certificate subject matches the specified {@code peerName} and that it was signed by a certificate authority known to the ESXi host. Verification is automatically enabled if you specify a {@code thumbprint} or {@code peerName}.
{@code cipherList=value} - Specifies a list of SSL ciphers. See OpenSSL ciphers. The ciphers are specified as a list separated by colons, spaces, or commas.

For information about URI format, see RFC 2396. | `string` | No |
| `PIPE` | Backing used to associate a virtual serial port with a named pipe. You can use a pipe to connect a virtual serial port to a host application or to another virtual machine on the host computer. This is useful for capturing debugging information sent through the virtual serial port. | `string` | No |
| `THIN_PRINT` | Backing that connects a virtual serial port with a ThinPrint device. | `string` | No |

## com_vmware_vcenter_vdcs_shares__info

**Description:** The {@name SharesInfo} {@term structure} specifies the shares information of resources.

Shares are used to determine relative allocation between resource consumers. In general, a consumer with more shares gets proportionally more of the resource, subject to certain other constraints.

### Attributes

| Name | Description | Type | Read-only |
| :--- | :--- | :--- | :--- |
| `level` | The simplified view of shares for allocation level. Levels map to a pre-determined set of numeric values for shares. If the shares value does not map to a predefined size, then the level is set as {@link SharesLevel#CUSTOM}. | `com_vmware_vcenter_vdcs_shares__info_shares__level` | No |
| `shares` | The number of shares allocated. Used to determine resource allocation in case of resource contention. This value is only set if level is set to {@link SharesLevel#CUSTOM}. Otherwise, it is ignored. Therefore, only shares with custom values can be compared.

There is no unit for this value. It is a relative measure based on the settings for other virtual machines. | `number` | No |

## com_vmware_vcenter_vdcs_shares__info_shares__level

**Description:** The {@name SharesLevel} {@term enumerated type} defines the type of share levels. These designations have different meanings for different resources.

### Attributes

| Name | Description | Type | Read-only |
| :--- | :--- | :--- | :--- |
| `CUSTOM` | If you specify CUSTOM for the level property, the server uses the share value to determine resource allocation when there is resource contention. | `string` | No |
| `HIGH` | HIGH is defined as the following:
For CPU: Shares = 2000 * number of virtual CPUs.
For Memory: Shares = 20 * virtual machine memory size in megabytes.
For Disk: Shares = 2000.
For Network: Shares = networkResourcePoolHighShareValue. The networkResourcePoolHighshareValue property implicitly defines the legal range of share values to be between 1 and this value. | `string` | No |
| `LOW` | LOW is defined as the following:
For CPU: Shares = 500 * number of virtual CPUs.
For Memory: Shares = 5 * virtual machine memory size in megabytes.
For Disk: Shares = 500.
For Network: Shares = 0.25 * networkResourcePoolHighShareValue. The networkResourcePoolHighshareValue property implicitly defines the legal range of share values to be between 1 and this value. | `string` | No |
| `NORMAL` | NORMAL is defined as the following:
For CPU: Shares = 1000 * number of virtual CPUs.
For Memory: Shares = 10 * virtual machine memory size in megabytes.
For Disk: Shares = 1000.
For Network: Shares = 0.5 * networkResourcePoolHighShareValue. The networkResourcePoolHighshareValue property implicitly defines the legal range of share values to be between 1 and this value. | `string` | No |

## com_vmware_vcenter_vdcs_V__app__customization__model

**Description:** Class containing the vApp configuration regarding product information, OVF properties, and IP assignment.

### Attributes

| Name | Description | Type | Read-only |
| :--- | :--- | :--- | :--- |
| `id` | Self identifier | `string` | No |
| `product` | Information about the content of the vApp.

This is described as a map of entries each indexed by a unique product key. The key is as follows:

For default product: 'product'
If both classId and instanceId are set: 'product-<classId>.<instanceId>'
If either classId or instanceId are set: 'product-<classId>' or 'product-<instanceId>'
Where 'classId' and 'instanceId' are the same as described in the {@link ProductSpec} class.

Unless 'classId' and 'instanceId' are both unset, the values must match the key in the map according to the above described format.

When a ProductSpec is created and 'classId' is not specified in the product itself, it is assigned the part after 'product-' of the map key. 'instanceId' is assigned the empty string.

For example if the map key is 'product-a.b' then 'classId' is assigned 'a.b'.

By default the "product" product section always exists.

Removal of product is specified by setting the product's key as the key, with the value in the Map set to null. | `Properties` | No |
| `ip_assignment` | Specifies the IP assignment schemes supported on this vApp.

Defaults to an {@link IpAssignment} with all attributes set to default values. | `com_vmware_vcenter_vdcs_ip__assignment` | No |
| `property` | A map of properties indexed with the fully-qualified id.

The key for the property is of the form:
'property-[<classId.>]id[<.instanceId>]'

Where 'classId', 'id, and 'instanceId' are the same as described in the {@link PropertySpec} class.

Unless 'classId', 'id, and 'instanceId' are all unset, the values must match the key in the map according the above described format.

When a PropertySpec is created and 'id' is not specified in the property itself, 'id' is assigned the part after 'property-' of the map key. 'classId' and 'instanceId' is assigned the empty string.

For example if the map key is 'property-a.b.c' then 'id' is assigned 'a.b.c'.

Defaults to the empty map.

Removal of property is specified by setting the property key as the key, with the value in the Map set to null. | `Properties` | No |
| `eulas` | End User License Agreements.

Defaults to the empty list | `Array/string` | No |

## com_vmware_vcenter_vdcs_V__app__startup__model

**Description:** Model for vAppStartup service.

### Attributes

| Name | Description | Type | Read-only |
| :--- | :--- | :--- | :--- |
| `start_action` | What to do when the containing vApp is started | `com_vmware_vcenter_vdcs_V__app__startup__model_start__action` | No |
| `start_delay_seconds` | Delay before starting the next group. The value must be 0 or higher, and less than 2147483648.

This field is not used for vApps.

Default value for VMs is 120. | `number` | No |
| `start_order` | Specifies the start order for this VM or vApp. VMs and vApps are started from lower numbers to higher numbers and reverse on shutdown. Multiple objects with the same start order can be started in parallel and the order is unspecified. This value must be 0 or higher, and less than 2147483648.

Default value is depending on the containing vApp and what other entities it contains. If the containing vApp only contains this VM or vApp the value is 1, otherwise it is 1 larger than the largest startOrder for any other VM or vApp in the containing vApp. | `number` | No |
| `stop_action` | What to do when the containing vApp is stopped | `com_vmware_vcenter_vdcs_V__app__startup__model_stop__action` | No |
| `stop_delay_seconds` | Delay before vApp shutdown will proceed to stop the next group. The value must be 0 or higher, and less than 2147483648.

This field is not used for vApps.

Default value for VMs is 120. | `number` | No |
| `waiting_for_guest` | Flag indicating if a VM should be considered started when a heartbeat is received from the guest.

The startup of a vApp will proceed with the next group (as defined by startOrder) when either it has waited for the time specified by startDelaySeconds or a heartbeat from the guest is received.

This field is not used for vApps.

The default value for VMs is false. | `boolean` | No |

## com_vmware_vcenter_vdcs_vm__customization__settings__model

**Description:** The {@name VmCustomizationSettingsModel} {@term structure} represents the customization settings specific extension for the virtual machine.

Unset or partially defined {@term fields} will receive default values based on the chosen guest operating system.

### Attributes

| Name | Description | Type | Read-only |
| :--- | :--- | :--- | :--- |
| `id` | Identifier of the virtual machine. | `string` | No |
| `product` | Information about the content of the virtual machine.

This is described as a {@term map} of entries each indexed by a unique product key. The key is of the form:
{@code product-[classId].[instanceId]}

Where {@code classId} and {@code instanceId} correspond to {@link ProductSpec#classId} and {@link ProductSpec#instanceId} respectively.

The above format implies the default product is indexed by the {@code product} key since both the {@code classId} and the {@code instanceId} are empty.

Removal of a product is specified by setting the product's key as the key, with the value in the {@term map} set to {@term unset}. | `Properties` | No |
| `ip_assignment` | Specifies the IP assignment schemes supported on this virtual machine. {@link IpAssignment} has an {@link IpAssignment.AllocationScheme} which defines various values. | `com_vmware_vcenter_vdcs_ip__assignment` | No |
| `property` | A {@term map} of properties indexed with the fully-qualified identifier.

The key for the property is of the form:
{@code property-[classId].[id].[instanceId]}

Where {@code classId} and {@code instanceId} correspond to {@link PropertySpec#classId} and {@link PropertySpec#instanceId} respectively.

Removal of a property is specified by setting the property key as the key, with the value in the {@term map} set to {@term unset}. | `Properties` | No |
| `eulas` | End user license agreements. | `Array/string` | No |
| `install_boot_required` | Indicates that the virtual machine needs to be booted once before the deployment is complete. | `boolean` | No |
| `install_boot_stop_delay` | Specifies the delay in seconds to wait for the virtual machine to power off after the initial boot. Only used if {@link #installBootRequired} is true. | `number` | No |

#### `com_vmware_vcenter_vdcs_vm__storage`
Auto-generated constructor

**Parameters:**
| Name | Type | Description |
| :--- | :--- | :--- |

#### `get`
Gets the {@name VmStorageModel} that corresponds to the given virtual machine identifier.

**Parameters:**
| Name | Type | Description |
| :--- | :--- | :--- |
| `vm_id` | `string` | Virtual machine identifier. |

**Returns:** `com_vmware_vcenter_vdcs_vm__storage__model`

#### `update`
Updates the storage related settings of the virtual machine. If a {@term field} is left {@term unset}, that {@term field} will not be updated. This applies to the nested structures as well, for example, if only the size {@term field} of a disk has a value, the size of the disk is updated, but all other values are left as is. For the {@param.name vmStorage} disk {@term map}, missing elements are treated as an unset {@term field}, and left unchanged. For example, if the disk {@term map} consists of a single entry with key equal to {@code scsi0:1} and value equal to a {@link DiskModel} with {@link DiskModel#capacity} equal to {@code 4096}, then it will update the capacity of {@code scsi0:1}, but will leave all other disks unchanged. If a device with the given device identifier already exists, the device is updated. Otherwise, a new device is created. In case of creation, any unset {@term field} will be assigned default values based on the chosen guest operating system. Removal of devices is specified by setting the device's device identifier as the key in the {@term map} of devices, with the value in the {@term map} set to {@term unset}.

**Parameters:**
| Name | Type | Description |
| :--- | :--- | :--- |
| `vm_id` | `string` | Virtual machine identifier. |
| `vm_storage` | `com__vmware__vcenter__vdcs__vm____storage____model` | The updated storage related settings for the virtual machine. |

**Returns:** `void`

---

## com_vmware_vcenter_vdcs_vm__storage__model

**Description:** The {@name VmStorageModel} provides storage specific extension for the virtual machine.

Unset or partially defined {@term fields} will receive default values based on the chosen guest operating system.

Disk controllers need not be added explicitly. IDE controllers are always present and SCSI and SATA disk controllers will be added automatically to support the configured disks and CD-ROMs. For example, if a SCSI disk is explicitly configured for the virtual machine, a SCSI controller of the default type for the OS will be added to the virtual machine.

If {@link #disks} is {@term unset}, a single disk will be added to the virtual machine with the default size for the OS.

For virtual machine update, the device identifier in the {@link DiskControllerModel} itself can be left unset. For deletion, the key of the {@term map} should be set to the device identifier of the device to delete, and the value should be set to {@term unset}. | `Properties` | No |
